SAI_PORT_ATTR_MAX_FEC_ERRORS_DETECTABLE could be used to determine the number of counters to collect if desired.

example code of how a NOS should read and interpret it.

The example is as follows:

We have a route entry with an action selector:
```
    /**
     * @brief Packet action
     *
     * @type sai_packet_action_t
     * @flags CREATE_AND_SET
     * @default SAI_PACKET_ACTION_FORWARD
     */
    SAI_ROUTE_ENTRY_ATTR_PACKET_ACTION = SAI_ROUTE_ENTRY_ATTR_START,
```

And another attribute that is an object:
```
    /**
     * @brief Next hop or next hop group id for the packet, or a router interface
     * in case of the directly reachable route or the CPU port in case of IP2ME route
     *
     * The next hop id is only effective when the packet action is one of the
     * following: FORWARD, COPY, LOG, TRANSIT.
     *
   ...
     *
     * When it is SAI_NULL_OBJECT_ID, then the packet will be dropped.
     *
     * @type sai_object_id_t
     * @flags CREATE_AND_SET
     * @objects SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_NEXT_HOP, SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_NEXT_HOP_GROUP, SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_ROUTER_INTERFACE, SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_PORT
     * @allownull true
     * @default SAI_NULL_OBJECT_ID
     */
    SAI_ROUTE_ENTRY_ATTR_NEXT_HOP_ID,
```

The next hop ID only makes sense if the action is not DROP. If the action is FORWARD, and next hop ID is NULL, it is just another way of saying action == DROP.

There may be action selectors other than sai_packet_action_t that don't allow for drop and object attributes like next hop ID cannot be NULL, which the metadata checker does not allow for today.

in this change, the dest port(egress port base one some route or forward rule) is moved to port1, could it be more dynamic, like binding the dest port when create the forwarding rule in fdb table, route? like a object for simulate the dest device with a certain ip, and that device have a dest port, and that port index defined in that device.
when create route we set

device.ip = 1.0.0.1
device.egress_port_index = 1

and when testing
verify_packet(self, device.egress_port_index)

by this way, we can define the dest port when create the config (still can use previous basic_test class), and can make the adjustment base on the actual device?

> in this change, the dest port(egress port base one some route or forward rule) is moved to port1, could it be more dynamic, like binding the dest port when create the forwarding rule in fdb table, route? like a object for simulate the dest device with a certain ip, and that device have a dest port, and that port index defined in that device. when create route we set
> 
> device.ip = 1.0.0.1 device.egress_port_index = 1
> 
> and when testing verify_packet(self, device.egress_port_index)
> 
> by this way, we can define the dest port when create the config (still can use previous basic_test class), and can make the adjustment base on the actual device?

Do I understand correctly your suggestion?
Ixia has a feature to create virtual hosts with IPs to send traffic. PTF doesn't have this. But what you suggest is to create object that will store endpoint information. So when we do IP configuration (e.g. in sairif.py:L3InterfaceSimplifiedTest.setUp() we do not rely on portN and dev_portN numbers, but rather define self.device1.ingress_port_index & self.device1.egress_port_index at this stage to use them in test cases.

We can create those self.deviceN in sai_base_test.py:SaiHelperUtilsMixin:create_routing_interfaces() and fill in ingress_port_index/ip and egress_port_index/ip values in setUp() methods, when we add actual IP configuration.

So tests will rely on deviceN and not on portN/dev_portN configuration.

As this is an improvement and not an issue with the current implementation I would like to have this in a separate PR. Is this OK?

We already started this improvement implementation for the new tests. Once we have finalized look and feel of it, we can update existing tests. It doesn't look like a big change, but it will require a lot of renaming in all test suites from the PR #1592 as well. So I would like to separate this work.

Hi Ravi,

There is no constraint from the SAI spec perspective but we do not provide
the same attribute id in the create call in current SAI implementation.

As far as the query is concerned, it is for a specific attribute id value.
Attribute in itself is not very useful and similarly querying at the object
level is not useful either.
We want granularity at each attribute id and its value.

-Jai

Yes, that's the purpose of the backup role - to not accept new connections unless explicitly said to. If the desired behavior is to accept connections immediately without waiting for a new peer, two peers may be configured to active role. Then in case of failure new connections will be accepted immediately without any direction from a controller.

Counter does not have any mandatory attribute to identify object uniquely. Adding a label attribute that can be used to uniquely identify object during warmboot scenarios. This is similar to existing label attribute used by LAG and virtual router.
The attribute is considered as user data attached to the object.

Related to:
https://github.com/opencomputeproject/SAI/pull/1158

Signed-off-by: Midhun Somasundaran [msomasundaran@fb.com](mailto:msomasundaran@fb.com)

yes, it should be excluded
This commit adds 8-lanes port interface types: CR8, KR8, SR8, LR8.

if you include experimental in existing sai_object_key_t, you will not have to modify any metadata utils or parser, and it will save many changes and usages if/else whether objects is experimental or not

My initial thinking was to follow `sai_object_type_t` extension to have a new type instead of having `saitypes.h` modified.

Including experimental headers in `SAI/inc` has not been done before. Is that an acceptable approach?

i think this could be discussed on nearest SAI community meeting, im not sure which one is best solution
* whether include experimental headers in sai/inc, and not need to change anything else
* or add separate type (as you added) and touch parsers, and later on swss and sairedis to check whenever object type is experimental

im worrying that making experimental check propagating over dependent repos, will cause this to fall apart at some time, and maintaining this could be challanging

Updating after review in SAI meeting on Jan 20, 2022:

1. A query mechanism can be used to check if a specific SAI implementation supports the NAT aging mechanism. The NOS can then query using sai_query_attribute_capability() API as follows:

    sai_query_attribute_capability(gSwitchId, SAI_OBJECT_TYPE_NAT_ENTRY, SAI_NAT_ENTRY_ATTR_AGING_TIME, &capability);
 
  The returned 'capability' would indicate if SAI supports NAT aging



2. NOS can use an optional switch attribute SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_NAT_EVENT_NOTIFY_INTERVAL to inform SAI on frequency of invoking the sai_nat_event_notification_fn callback.

  If this attribute is not specified or if attribute set to 0 (i.e. default), SAI notifies NOS as soon as NAT entry is aged out.
  SAI can still do bulking of notifications even when this interval is 0.
 
 
    /**
     * @brief NAT event notification callback timeout in seconds
     *
     * SAI to notify NOS through the sai_nat_event_notification_fn callback at specified duration
     *
     * @type sai_uint32_t
     * @flags CREATE_AND_SET
     * @default 0
     */
    SAI_SWITCH_ATTR_NAT_EVENT_NOTIFY_INTERVAL,
